problem.para: For the interval pairs below, sketch their cartesian products in \RNr[2]

answer.para: The product of the given intervals is [-3,6]\times [4,9]. It is the rectangle in \RNr[2] with corner points

li.para: The interval [-3,6] is the space of 1-tuples (x) with -3\leq x\leq 6.
The interval [4,9] is the space of 1-tuples (y) with 4\leq y\leq 9.

solution.hint.para: Therefore the product of the intervals is a space of 2-tuples (x,y). – Which?

answer.para: The product of the given intervals is [4,9]\times [-3,6]. It is the rectangle in \RNr[2] with corner points

li.para: The interval [4,9] is the space of 1-tuples (y) with 4\leq y\leq 9.
The interval [-3,6] is the space of 1-tuples (x) with -3\leq x\leq 6.

solution.hint.para: Therefore the product of the intervals is a space of 2-tuples (x,y). – Which?

Notice the difference between this and the previous problem: interchanging the order in which we multiply the intervals matters: The rectangle [4,9]\times [-3,6] results from reflecting the rectangle [-3,6]\times [4,9] over the line of all points of the form (t,t).
